metadata.title: Supporting Information Incorporating uracil and 5-halouracils into short peptide nucleic acids for enhanced recognition of A-U pairs in dsRNAs

body_text.text: Compounds (1-5) were synthesized following the reported procedure and their 1 H NMR spectra were found to be identical as those reported (1-3).

(2,4-Dioxo-3,4-dihydro-1(2H)-pyrimidinyl)acetic acid (1). The isolated yield is 56%. 1 (5-Fluoro-2,4-dioxo-3,4-dihydro-1(2H)-pyrimidinyl)acetic acid (2) . The isolated yield is 51%. General procedure for the synthesis of compounds 11-15: Compound 6-10 (500 mg) was dissolved in THF (10 mL) and stirred in an ice bath. Aqueous LiOH (1 M, 1 mL) was added dropwise and the reaction mixture was allowed to stir at room temperature for 0.5 h. Additional aqueous LiOH was added if the TLC analysis showed the presence of the unreacted ester. Upon completion of the reaction, THF was evaporated using a rotary evaporator. The reaction mixture was then acidified by aqueous HCl (1 M) in an ice bath until the pH reaches 2-3. The obtained precipitate was filtered by a Büchner funnel, washed with cold water and stored under vacuum in a desiccator. In the case where no precipitate was formed during acidification, the reaction mixture was extracted by 5% MeOH in DCM. The removal of organic solvents under reduced pressure yielded the respective product as a foamy solid.
(11). The isolated yield is 79%. This compound exists as two rotamers. The chemical shifts for the minor rotamer are given in brackets. 1

BIBREF0.title: Mechanistic Studies of Antibody-Catalyzed Pyrimidine Dimer Photocleavage

BIBREF1.title: Synthesis and hybridization properties of DNA-PNA chimeras carrying 5-bromouracil and 5-methylcytosine

BIBREF3.title: Incorporating a guanidine-modified cytosine base into triplexforming PNAs for the recognition of a C-G pyrimidine-purine inversion site of an RNA duplex

FIGREF0.text: Non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to rHP1 at pH 7.5. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.5. The loaded samples contain 0.25 M of rHP1 in 25 L. The PNA concentrations in lanes from left to right are 0, 0.01, 0.02, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 1, 2, 4, 10 and 20 M, respectively.

FIGREF1.text: Kd determination by non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to rHP1 at pH 7.5. The fraction of triplex formation was calculated based on equation Y = Itriplex/(Itriplex + aIduplex). The band intensities were normalized according to a = Itriplex max/ Iduplex max. Iduplex max is the band intensity for hairpin alone without the addition of PNA. Itriplex max is the triplex band intensity with the highest concentration of PNA added. The data were fit to the equation: Y = Y0 + (B/2/R0)(R0 + X + Kd -((R0 + X + Kd) 2 -4R0X) 1/2 ) where R0 is the RNA hairpin concentration (0.25 µM). Y0 and B are the minimum and maximum fraction of triplex formation respectively. X is the total PNA concentration and Kd is the dissociation constant.

FIGREF2.text: Non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to rHP1 at pH 7.7. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.7. The loaded samples contain 0.25 M of rHP1 in 25 L. The PNA concentrations in lanes from left to right are (a) 0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 1, 1.6, 2, 4, 10, 16, 20, 28 and 50 M, respectively, and (b-k) 0, 0.01, 0.02, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 1, 2, 4, 10 and 20 M, respectively.

FIGREF3.text: Kd determination by non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to rHP1 at pH 7.7. The fraction of triplex formation was calculated based on equation Y = Itriplex/(Itriplex + aIduplex). The band intensities were normalized according to a = Itriplex max/ Iduplex max. Iduplex max is the band intensity for hairpin alone without the addition of PNA. Itriplex max is the triplex band intensity with the highest concentration of PNA added. The data were fit to the equation: Y = Y0 + (B/2/R0)(R0 + X + Kd -((R0 + X + Kd) 2 -4R0X) 1/2 ) where R0 is the RNA hairpin concentration (0.25 µM). Y0 and B are the minimum and maximum fraction of triplex formation respectively. X is the total PNA concentration and Kd is the dissociation constant.

FIGREF4.text: Non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to rHP1 at pH 8.0. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, pH 8.0. The loaded samples contain 0.25 M of rHP1 in 25 L. The PNA concentrations in lanes from left to right are 0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 1, 1.6, 2, 4, 10, 16, 20, 28 and 50 M, respectively.

FIGREF5.text: Kd determination by non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to rHP1 at pH 8.0. The fraction of triplex formation was calculated based on equation Y = Itriplex/(Itriplex + aIduplex). The band intensities were normalized according to a = Itriplex max/ Iduplex max. Iduplex max is the band intensity for hairpin alone without the addition of PNA. Itriplex max is the triplex band intensity with the highest concentration of PNA added. The data were fit to the equation: Y = Y0 + (B/2/R0)(R0 + X + Kd -((R0 + X + Kd) 2 -4R0X) 1/2 ) where R0 is the RNA hairpin concentration (0.25 µM). Y0 and B are the minimum and maximum fraction of triplex formation respectively. X is the total PNA concentration and Kd is the dissociation constant.

FIGREF6.text: Non-denaturing PAGE for P1 and various singly-modified PNAs binding to rHP5, rHP6 and rHP7. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.7. The loaded samples contain 1 M of RNA hairpin (rHP5, rHP6 and rHP7) in 20 L. The PNA concentrations in lanes from left to right are 016, 20, 28 and 50 M, respectively.

FIGREF7.text: Non-denaturing PAGE for various doubly-modified PNAs binding to rHP5, rHP6 and rHP7. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.7. The loaded samples contain 1 M of RNA hairpin (rHP5, rHP6 and rHP7) in 20 L. The PNA concentrations in lanes from left to right are 050 M, respectively.

FIGREF8.text: Non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to dHP1. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.7. The loaded samples contain 1 M of dHP1 in 10 L. The PNA concentrations in lanes from left to right are 0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 1, 1.6, 2, 4, 10, 16, 20, 28 and 50 M, respectively.

FIGREF9.text: Kd determination by non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to miR-198 precursor. Except for panel a, the fraction of triplex formation was calculated based on equation Y = Itriplex/(Itriplex + aIduplex). The band intensities were normalized according to a = Itriplex max/ Iduplex max. Iduplex max is the band intensity for hairpin alone without the addition of PNA. Itriplex max is the triplex band intensity with the highest concentration of PNA added. The data were fit to the equation: Y = Y0 + (B/2/R0)(R0 + X + Kd -((R0 + X + Kd) 2 -4R0X) 1/2 ) where R0 is the RNA hairpin concentration (1 µM). Y0 and B are the minimum and maximum fraction of triplex formation respectively. X is the total PNA concentration and Kd is the dissociation constant.

FIGREF10.text: Kd determination by non-denaturing PAGE for various PNAs binding to HIV-1 frameshift inducing RNA hairpin. The fraction of triplex formation was calculated based on equation Y = Itriplex/(Itriplex + aIduplex). The band intensities were normalized according to a = Itriplex max/ Iduplex max. Iduplex max is the band intensity for hairpin alone without the addition of PNA. Itriplex max is the triplex band intensity with the highest concentration of PNA added. The data were fit to the equation: Y = Y0 + (B/2/R0)(R0 + X + Kd -((R0 + X + Kd) 2 -4R0X) 1/2 ) where R0 is the RNA hairpin concentration (0.25 µM). Y0 and B are the minimum and maximum fraction of triplex formation respectively. X is the total PNA concentration and Kd is the dissociation constant.

FIGREF11.text: Non-denaturing PAGE study of P1 and BU-3,5 binding to rHP1 and dHP1 at 200 mM and 10 mM NaCl. The gels contain a running buffer of 1 TBE, pH 8.3 and was run for 5 hours at 250 V. The incubation buffer contains 10 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.5 (a-b), or 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, 2 mM MgCl2, pH 7.5 (c-d).(a-d) The loaded samples contain 0.25 M rHP1 in 25 L. The PNA concentrations in lanes from left to right are 0, 0.01, 0.02, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, 1, 2, 4, 10 and 20 M, respectively. The data shown in panels a and b suggest that lowering the NaCl concentration from 200 to 10 mM results in the stabilization of PNA•dsRNA triplex, but no strand invasion complex formation. The data shown in panels c and d suggest that addition of 2 mM MgCl2 results in the destabilization of PNA•dsRNA triplexes. However, PNA BU-3,5 still shows a relatively tight binding even in the presence of 2 mM MgCl2 (Kd values of 0.9 µM with 2 mM MgCl2 versus 0.3 µM without 2 mM MgCl2 (see Figure 3i)). (e) rHP1 (lanes 1-6) and dHP1 (lanes 7-12) loaded are at 1 M in 20 L and 10 L, respectively. The incubation buffer is 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.5, 200 mM NaCl (lane 1-3, 7-9) or 10 mM NaCl (lane 4-6, 10-12). The loaded samples contain no PNA (for lanes 1, 4, 7, and 10), or 10 M P1 (for lane 2, 5, 8, and 11), or 10 M BU-3,5 (for lane 3, 6, 9, and 12). The slow migrating bands shown in lanes 2, 3, 5, and 6 indicate the PNA•dsRNA triplex formation. No PNA•dsDNA triplex was observed. The relatively slow-moving and faint bands observed in lanes 11 and 12 indicate the formation of strand invasion complexes between PNA and dHP1. 5. CD spectra CD characterization of PNA binding to RNAs. The incubation buffer contains 100 mM NaCl, 10 mM sodium phosphate, pH 7.0. The RNA concentration is kept at 2 M in 100 L. The PNA concentrations are 4 M (a), 20 M (b), and 4M (c), respectively. (a,b) Binding to model RNA hairpins and miR-198 RNA hairpin. No helicity is observed for PNAs P1 and BU-3,5 (see panel a). The red shift of the peak at around 270 nm upon the binding of PNAs suggests the PNA•rHP1 and PNA•miR-198 hairpin triplex formation. No clear red shift was observed for the control BU-3,5 + rHP2 compared to rHP2 alone. rHP2 has the G9-C24 pair in rHP1 replaced with a C-G pair and does not bind to BU-3,5 (Data not shown). (c) Binding to miR-198 ssRNA (5′-GGGAGAUAGG-3′). No clear CD signal is observed for the sample containing 6-mer PNAs in the presence of miR-198 ssRNA, suggesting no stable PNA-RNA duplex formation. 6. Thermal melting results Thermal melting results for RNA-PNA duplexes containing singly-modified PNAs. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM NaH2PO4, pH 7.5. All samples contain 5 µM RNA and 5 µM PNA. Hysteresis between heating and cooling curves were observed. Melting curves for samples containing P1 and singlymodified PNAs with (a) ssRNA1 (5′-AGAGAAAG-3′) and (b) ssRNA2 (5′-GAAAGAGA-3′). (c,e,g,i,k,m) Heating and cooling curves of ssRNA1 with various singly-modified PNAs with PNAs binding to ssRNA1 in a parallel orientation. (d,f,h,j,l,n)Heating and cooling curves of ssRNA2 with various singly-modified PNAs with PNAs binding to ssRNA2 in an antiparallel orientation. Data shown in panels a and b were taken from a previous study(4).

FIGREF12.text: Thermal melting results for RNA-PNA duplexes containing doubly-modified PNAs. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM NaH2PO4, pH 7.5. All samples contain 5 µM RNA and 5 µM PNA. Hysteresis between heating and cooling curves were observed. Melting curves for samples containing P1 and doubly-modified PNAs with (a) ssRNA1 (5′-AGAGAAAG-3′) and (b) ssRNA2 (5′-GAAAGAGA-3′). (c,e,g,i,k) Heating and cooling curves of ssRNA1 with various doubly-modified PNAs with PNAs binding to ssRNA1 in a parallel orientation. (d,f,h,j,l) Heating and cooling curves of ssRNA2 (5′-GAAAGAGA-3′) with various doubly-modified PNAs with PNAs binding to ssRNA2 in an antiparallel orientation.

FIGREF13.text: Thermal melting results for potential miR-198 ssRNA-PNA duplexes. The incubation buffer contains 200 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA, 20 mM NaH2PO4, pH 7.5. All samples contain 5 µM RNA and 5 µM PNA. Hysteresis between heating and cooling curves was observed. The data suggest no strong binding between the PNAs and the miR-198 ssRNA (5′-GGGAGAUAGG-3′). The letter "X" in the PNA sequences represents a Br U residue. Confocal microscopic imaging studies of the HeLa cell uptake of carboxyfluoresein-labelled PNAs HIV-T,T-cf and HIV-BU,BU-cf at a final concentration of 1 µM. Hoechst 33258 was used for nuclei DNA staining. The PNAs are essentially not taken up by the HeLa cells.
